text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with mini Philly cheesesteaks
that's right not only are these fun
sized cheesesteaks beautiful and
delicious because we're chopping up the
steak they're very safe to eat
so unlike the Green Bay Packers there's
very little chance of choking but anyway
cheap shots aside
I thought these came out really really
well and this is how we're going to put
them together so first up we're going to
make a roux and of course that means
melting some butter over medium heat and
whisking in some flour and all we're
going to do is cook that stirring for a
couple minutes until it kind of turns
golden and believe it or not what we're
actually making here is a provolone
cheese whiz you see the age-old argument
in Philly is whether a cheesesteak is
best with provolone or Cheez Whiz so I
decided to take both ideas and do a
provolone cheese whiz and for that we
need a simple white sauce or bechamel
which is what we're making here so like
I said we're going to cook that butter
and flour for a few minutes until it
just starts to turn golden something
like this at which point we're going to
dump in 1 cup of milk that's right just
dump it all in and then stir and I know
you're nervous we should have added it
gradually and stirred as we went no it's
okay
hot rue cold milk equals no lumps and
once that's mixed in you're just going
to keep stirring and as it comes up to
temperature it will thicken
significantly so we'll just keep cooking
that on medium heat for a few minutes
until we have something that looks like
this at which point we can turn off the
heat and add the rest of the ingredients
which includes some cayenne pepper we'll
also do a little bit of freshly ground
nutmeg just a hint and of course a nice
big pinch of salt and we'll stir that in
and then last but not least I'm going to
tear up an add two slices of provolone
which is going to be about 2 or 3 ounces
worth depending on the size of course if
you're not using sliced provolone you
can just grade it that seems obvious and
all we need to do is stir that in until
it disappears and what we're left with
we're going to call a provolone cheese
whiz so a pretty simple little cheese
bread in fact the hardest part is
getting the whisk out of the mixture
come on come on there we go and once
that's done just grab a spatula and
transfer that into some kind of
container to reserve until needed
so our provolone cheese whiz is done and
at this point we can move
to the meat and of course for
cheesesteak you're going to need some
kind of steak and I'm going to recommend
you use skirt steak although my butcher
was out of it so I actually use flap
meat which is really really similar and
I'll give more info about the steak
choices on the blog but anyway I'm going
to use a nicely marbled piece of flat
meat pardon the expression but
regardless of the steak you're using we
want to season that very generously on
both sides with salt and freshly ground
black pepper and then I want you to cook
it any way you want I'm going to sear
mine in a hot pan you could grill it you
could broil it it really doesn't matter
as long as you cook it somewhere between
medium rare and medium so I went ahead
and I cooked my hunk of meat until I
thought it was nice and pink inside at
which point I'm going to remove that to
a plate to rest and if you do use a pan
to cook yours which I'm recommending of
course you're going to have a beautiful
found at the bottom of the pan and you
know what we do when we see a found so
I'm going to throw in a splash of water
and that liquid of course is going to
release all that amazing caramelize
goodness from the bottom of the pan
which we can now add to our resting
steak and then all we need to do is let
that meat cool completely before we dice
it up or if you try to cut that up when
it's hot you're going to lose way too
much moisture and it will get dry don't
forget we're going to cook this again
and if for whatever reason you lose the
Battle of willpower and just eat this
steak just like this no one would blame
you but if you are able to resist once
your meats cold we're going to go ahead
and dice it up nice and small
and how I like to do this I like to cut
strips with the grain okay in the same
direction the fibers are going and then
I'll turn those strips this way and cut
them into a nice small dice and of
course I started on the thin side so
that looks a little well done but you'll
see as we cut into it that meat is nice
and pink and juicy kind of a key here
cuz like I said we are going to cook it
again and once our meats diced up nice
and small we'll toss that in a bowl we
will pour over all those accumulated
juices and then just like a real Philly
cheese steak if you want we can add the
optional peppers and onions which we're
totally going to add so I added a nice
big spoonful of sauteed onions and
peppers which by the way sounds pretty
basic and it is but I'm actually going
to show you this as a separate video
because it wasn't just sauteed onions
and peppers it was actually a pickled
pepper onion relish that came out
incredibly well so I'm actually going to
post that separately as a little extra
bonus video so stay tuned for that but
anyway like I said we're going to mix in
some sauteed peppers and onion
and obviously this would be the perfect
point to taste for seasoning so taste
and adjust and at that point we can move
on to final assembly so for the base of
our mini cheese steak we're going to use
slices of baguette nice thick slices and
what we'll do is we'll place that down
on a foil lined sheet pan and we'll
drizzle it with some olive oil or melted
butter up to you but just on one side
once we drizzle that over the top we'll
flip those over so the oil sides down
and we can move on to spreading these
with our provolone cheese whiz so take a
knife or a spreader and put on a fairly
generous amount and not only is this
going to provide cheesy goodness
underneath our steak it's also going to
help keep this bite very moist and
succulent so make sure you're slathering
it on nice and thick getting down into
all those nooks and crannies and just
when you think you've put out enough
grab a little bit extra and spread some
more on just to be safe so that looks
good and then once our breads been
cheesed we'll top that with a generous
spoonful of our chopped steak mixture so
pile it up nice and high like you see
here and once that's been done the final
and most important step the top cheese
so we got our cheese whiz underneath but
I'm also going to do some strips of
provolone over the top some racing
stripes if you will and again if you
bought a chunk of provolone you can just
grate it and sprinkle it over but if you
got a slice like me just cut some strips
like this I believe in French that's
baton to fromage if I'm not mistaken and
I'm being a little bit reserved here if
you want to top these with a little more
cheese use a little more I mean you are
the Sylvester Stalone of your provolone
so I'm going to go around and add some
more provolone to the top of those at
which point those are ready to place in
the center of a 400 degree oven for
about 12 to 15 minutes or until they
look like this if everything's gone
according to plan they should look
pretty gorgeous that cheese on top will
have started to bubble and brown and
don't be surprised if you're me Kyle
caramelized around the edges and that's
pretty much it we'll go ahead and
transfer those onto some kind of serving
platter
maybe garnish with some freshly chopped
chives and those mini Philly
cheesesteaks are done and these really
were amazing
just beautiful contrasting textures
between the crispy edges and bottom and
that soft cheese wizzy Center just a
beautiful combination and the taste
pretty much exactly like a provolone
based Philly cheesesteak and if you do
use a skirt steak or the flat meat like
I did you're going to get a beautiful
beefy steak flavor
despite looking all browned and
caramelized those pieces of meat are
still very tender very moist so I was
just absolutely thrilled with how great
these came out sure there was a bunch of
steps and a lot of components but most
of it you could do way ahead of time and
then you can just assemble and bake when
you're ready to eat so I really do hope
you give this a try head over to food
wishes comm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
